lesson.name: Unit 4: Part 2: Community Needs Assessment and Evaluating PD

page.title: Critical Questions for Community Needs Assessment
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4090.mp3

Audio Transcript


Preparing English learners for work and careers requires a good sense of the demographics of a community and an interest in such a project by potential learners. This preparation also requires up-to-date data on the local economy, including the employment picture. You also may want to find out more about career and technical opportunities that exist in your area and how well they meet the needs of students not yet proficient in English.

These questions will give you some ideas of where to start.

  • Who are the immigrants and refugees in our community who could benefit from a contextualized English language acquisition (ELA) program?

  • To what extent are ELLs high skilled and to what extent low skilled?

  • What job training, ELA, and support services are currently available for different groups, including learners at high beginning/low intermediate levels of proficiency?

  • What jobs do ELLs tend to hold? What employers offer jobs that support ongoing education and training?

page.title: Community Needs Assessment
page.contents:
About Community Needs Assessments


Community needs assessments take many forms: sometimes as “environmental scans” to determine which providers are “touching” immigrants through various services. The needs assessments often include demographic information and data on demands of jobs in the local area, as well as information on the technical classes that are available to for students who may have training and experience in a particular field but whose English is still not perfect. Your city or your Workforce Board may have conducted such a scan, but the results may not speak directly to the career opportunities available (or not available) to English learners.

It may be up to you to gather a group interested in focusing on the availability of services for immigrants and refugees in the workforce who are still learning English but are ready to move up a career ladder. Your partners may be able to share resources and expertise to help create an assessment that can guide both current and future efforts.

Here are some sources of information that will give you a detailed picture of  needs and opportunities in your community:

  1. Review of census data (American Community Survey) for information on different groups

  2. Interviews with immigrant-serving agencies  

  3. Focus groups with different groups of immigrants and refugees to gauge interest

  4. A scan of social service agencies providing support services, such as child care and transportation vouchers

  5. Discussions with members of workforce boards and employers to identify job opportunities

  6. Talks with training providers, including community colleges, that offer career pathway programs appropriate for ELLs

page.title: Bright Idea: A Steering Commitee
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4100.mp3

Audio Transcript


If you are a new program embarking on a broad effort to link English learners with jobs and with occupational skills training or if you are new to serving immigrants and refugees not yet fluent in English, you might set up a steering committee. Such a committee can tell you about community needs and resources, and make you aware of family support services that your students can access.

The city of Seattle has been convening such a committee as part of its Ready To Work program for beginning and intermediate level English learners. Look at the agencies that are part of this committee. Are there any agencies that you think are important but that are not represented? If you were to set up such a committee for your local area, whom would you ask to participate? Who might convene such a committee?

The Office of Immigrant and Refugee Affairs (OIRA) in Seattle has set up a steering committee for its Ready to Work bridge program. The committee helps define community needs from multiple perspectives.

Member agencies include the following:

  • Community colleges offering courses for ELLs, as well as career/technical training courses

  • Local service providers from community-based organizations serving immigrants and refugees  

  • Refugee resettlement agencies helping individuals get a foothold in the economy

  • The county’s Workforce Development Council

  • Seattle Housing Authority offering subsidized housing to low-income residents

A steering committee can help define the philosophy and direction of a program and offer insights into and data regarding needs. Such a committee can also help conduct focus groups with potential students.

Does your program have a steering committee for your bridge program or career pathway? If so, what organizations are represented? Do you have lessons learned or tips for others? If not, what organizations would you like to have represented and why? Discuss these questions with your Community of Practice, or with colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Focus Groups with Immigrants and Refugees
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4110.mp3

Audio Transcript


Even after you have started your program, a needs assessment can help you see if you are on the right track or if you might be missing a component. Students should certainly participate in these discussions, and an area-wide focus group (or even one just for your program) can provide you with valuable information about the needs, backgrounds, and circumstances of potential and actual English learners.

Five actions to consider when setting up focus groups with immigrants and refugees:

  1. Ask agencies with direct links to the community to do outreach.

  2. Make sure interpreters are available so that members can speak in a language they are comfortable with.

  3. Promise confidentiality and get releases from participants.

  4. Offer refreshments and gifts for participating, if your budget allows.

  5. Ask creative questions (e.g., “If you wake up tomorrow morning and you speak perfect English, what will you do?”).

Guide to focus groups with ELLs

page.title: What a Focus Group Can Tell You
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4120.mp3

Audio Transcript


In Seattle, students from different areas in the city participated in bilingual focus groups lead by an experienced facilitator. You can see the results here. Do any of the results surprise you? Why? If you look at the students whom you serve, would the findings be essentially similar or would they be quite different? What could you do to get a sound picture of the backgrounds, circumstances, and needs of potential students?

To help shape its Ready To Work program, the Office of Immigrant and Refugee Affairs in Seattle conducted focus groups in four different locations with 83 immigrants and refugees. Here are some of their key findings, based on answers from members of the focus groups:

  • A total of 55% had not worked in the United States.

  • A total of 61% had not worked in their home country.

  • A total of 70% of individuals who wanted to get a job or be promoted in a job were not sure what they wanted to do or what steps to take.

  • A total of 80% were not proficient computer users.

page.title: Program Review
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4130.mp3

Audio Transcript


A broad needs assessment and a thorough program review will offer you information, insights, and judgements as well as solid numbers based on measurements. This then allows you to analyze both quantitative data as well as qualitative data. Taking together these findings help you to document the strengths of your program and point you toward future directions. But an analysis and interpretation of results also help you to pinpoint weaknesses and gaps in your services and show you where you might not be quite as successful as you had hoped. Perhaps you are not retaining students with lower education levels long enough so they are ready to transition. Perhaps your expectations for more educated students are not high enough to allow them to transition faster?

It’s important to look at your findings from all angles. As part of this process you might consider not only including inside partners, most importantly your eachers, but also outside partners involved in education, workforce development, training, and immigrant integration.

If you want to learn more about the different program models you might consider, check out Unit 2 on Program Design: Issues and Options. And Unit 3 Bright Ideas for Curriculum and Instruction offers strategies for preparing students for more the more rigorous work required in transition classes.

The findings from your needs assessment and your program review should yield answers to the following:

  • What are the most likely training courses that English learners  might transition to?
  • What is the most appropriate model for preparing our students for skills training? (bridge classes, concurrent enrollment, team taught integrated courses?)
  • What proportion of our students are ready to transition and  what proportion are students with limited schooling?
  • How many of our students have transitioned to occupational skills classes?  How many have completed?
  • What supports helped our students advance ? What were barriers to success, and what did we do to reduce these?
  • What is the profile of students who drop out of our program? What can we do to serve this group better in the future?

page.title: Evaluating Professional Development
page.contents:
Listen to audio

ELL_Mod3_4140.mp3

Audio Transcript


The Workforce Investment and Opportunity Act of 2014 calls for high-quality PD in adult education and training.

The RAND Corporation study suggests that teachers matter more to student achievement than does any other aspect of schooling. Although non-school factors do influence achievement, schools have little control over these factors—but they can offer PD that focuses on improving student outcomes.

English Language Acquisition teachers and instructors teaching career/technical training courses need PD that helps them meet the needs of career pathway students.

The research in teaching suggests that a good teacher is often a strong factor in student achievement. But how do you know whether the PD training your teachers attend makes a difference in their knowledge and skills, leads to changes in teaching, and influences what students learn?

Thomas Guskey has developed a model that describes five levels of evaluating PD. This model is a useful measure for determining whether PD is making a difference.

To learn more about a framework for quality PD for programs serving ELLs, see  the Center for Adult English Language Acquisition (CAELA) brief, Framework for Quality Professional Development for Practitioners Working With Adult English Language Learners

page.title: Five Levels of Evaluating PD
page.contents:
What are your thoughts as you look at Thomas Guskey’s model for evaluating PD? Do you agree with these categories? If not, why not? As an administrator, could you use this model? As a teacher, do you think it captures what you have taken away from PD and the changes you have made in your teaching?

Guskey’s scheme for capturing the effectiveness of professional development has five levels of measurement and assessment, including the impact of PD on an organization.

Critical Levels of PD Evaluation include:

1.A teacher’s initial reaction to the experience
2.A teacher’s acquisition of new knowledge and skills
3.Changes in an organization’s advocacy, support, accommodations, facilitation, and recognition
4.A teacher’s degree of implementing and applying the new skills
5.Student learning outcomes, including outcomes related to achievement and to student attitudes and dispositions

Now try it yourself:  Download the  attached Word document and think about questions you will ask to evaluate PD related to Preparing English Learners for Work and Career Pathways

To learn more please click on the link for Does It Make a Difference? Evaluating Professional Development

Guskey, T. R. (2002). Does it make a difference? Evaluating professional development. Educational Leadership, 59(6), 45-51.
